item.title: It Is Too Soon to Panic on AngularJS 2.0

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: If it isn't broken don't fix it! It's simple, in my opinion.If Angular 1.x works for you and you don't have the resources to upgrade, don't.If Angular 1.x works for you, why bother upgrading anyway? Because it's new? Only if it gives you tangible benefits it makes sense. And if it does, the benefits can be weighed against the cost to make a rational decision. And if at this point in time upgrading doesn't weigh up to the cost? Re-evaluate at some point in the future.Really don't see a problem here, just glad people like the Angular team keep things moving :)

As a follow-up to my previous comment, there is a post today on the Durandal blog comparing an Angular 2.0 to-do app with an Aurelia version. http://blog.durandal.io/2015/05/20/porting-an-angular-2-0-app-to-aurelia/After skimming the blog post and the code sample comparisons, the code cleanliness of Aurelia far outweighs the Angular 2.0 version. The funky characters Angular 2.0 introduces into its html binding syntax look seriously obscure and non-developer friendly. I have trouble seeing how a developer would actually look forward to use such a syntax in their html. My concern now is not, "How to migrate to Angular 2.0", but rather, "How to migrate to Aurelia", and be glad that in the meantime Angular 1.x still has support from the Angular team.
@Dirk +1There are to many children in this industry...
i get that semantic versioning means a rev number can mean a breaking change, but complete incompatibilty isn't what people expect.

Great balanced post."Sure it may involve a re-write"I like how you say that so cavalierly. If I were in the spot, It would not be fun to see the reaction of the business that just sunk a million dollars into the AngularJs experiment just to find out there is no future there for the investment that they just made. Statements like "you're gonna need a rewrite" immediately after making an investment make software developers look like scam artists. I hate to perpetuate that just because we wanted to try something new and shiny.At the very least, Pluralsight will get a few more AngularJs videos to put in their library :P

it is simple to speak about necesary changes if you don't have to fund the development. it is more serious if you fund e.g. $ 1mil project with large team and in 2 years you have to partialy rewrite it.

Perhaps the Angular team announced too much of 2.0 too early, I don't understand why everyone is so surprised that a web technology is going to change, ummm duh!The angular team does need to commit to maintaining the 1.3 version as a legacy version for 2 more years or they will lose the confidence of developers.For those developers that have a problem with the changes in Angular 2.0 I suggest you look for a new line of work. This industry is not for those intolerant of change. Code written today using open source libraries will have a max supported life span of no more than two years. Every project will eventually fall into legacy maintenance mode. That is why Modularization is so important.There is a revolution coming in the web development world. ES6+web components. If you dislike the syntax and methodology of Angular 2.0 then you will not like ES6. Everything you know now will be changing and is changing as we speak. Start learning now! or else you will be left behind with the flash developers.

Well written article, this stuff happens all the time with frameworks. As the web matures and changes, so do frameworks. Which unfortunately means rewrite most of the time.I almost question folks who put all their eggs in the Angular 1.+ platform. New framework, bound to have tons of changes moving forward. I almost like to let frameworks and languages work out their kinks before I put tons of development time into them.

I don't know why all this negativity about AngularJS 2.0. The team just put forward the plan and path about what AngularJS 2.0 will take based on lot of factor (developer feedback, ES 6.0, may be competition etc). So they can be transparent with future direction.Only concern is how long they are going to support/maintain Angularjs 1.3 after that.So guys chill out a bit and provide constructive feedback so it can help everybody.

Superb post and say advice.I confess that I winced at "complete rewrite". This is not like changing your socks. It's not a personal decision to rewrite a corporate app. Frankly, I'm hopeful of a more graceful glide path from v1 to v2 and a way to migrate module by module rather than in a big bang. We look for similar opportunities today when we migrate an MVC app to a SPA, for example.But your overall argument is on the money.Every project started today must face squarely the virtual certainty that whatever you choose technology will be "old" in two or three years. Doesn't matter what it is or who provides it. We should budget and build for that ... which may mean a readiness to stay on "legacy" tech and be content.I think the Ng team should be more sensitive to this issue. And we developers could be more understanding.

Well stated Shawn.The battle for the Web is well under way and long from being won. In the past 5 years we've been through a whirlwind of technology. I didn't use Angular because I expected it in its exact form it is today to be the same and not evolve ... I expect change. Is it always comfortable? No. I've written SPA's in Knockout, vanilla.js, Durandal, Angular, and others. Using all of those gave me a good sense of why I use them and what I prefer. Every project has to be evaluated on the information you have n front of you We can't guess at future state. This Web world changes all the time ... best advice is to keep your ears open, constantly reevaluate, question everything, and provide feedback to the decision makers in a constructive way.Great post man!

Thank you for the article, and especially you guys who posted in the comments section.This discussion and having read up other pieces on 2.0 has helped me stave off a huge mistake going with this framework.A project that changes the fundamental architecture and interfaces is *not* something I deem as dependable nor willing to invest in. I'm looking for a project with a stable vision and that cares for its installed base and community. Obviously Angular is not it.The search continues, but it seems web frameworks may be a bad idea in general. Instead picking individual libraries needed such as jquery, backbone etc. that have proven stable may be the right option as the risk of all of those project suddenly waking up one day and changing direction 180 degrees is much less likely. Not to mention a chance to avoid the accidental complexity and learning curve (cost) that frameworks as such are plagued with.

I think the way you start your post is spot on: "The angular team is finally talking more publicly about what they are trying to do." As somebody who has been fairly critical over the team's communication efforts, I take several things from your opening line. First, it remains unclear precisely what they are trying to do. Second, as efforts are focused on 2, that will mean less resources for 1.x. It also remains to be seen how much more communication there will be. I've seen the latest and greatest here: www.github.com/angular/angular and candidly, there's not much there. The very things that drove people to Angular 1.x appear to be antithetical to 2.0. I for one am not in panic mode and I don't think anybody should be in panic mode. 1.3 is here and people can stay on that for as long as necessary. If 2.0 is better and has a clear value proposition, people will migrate to it. Otherwise, people will reject it. By the way, were not just talking about people. There are enterprises as well. The comments made by the team at ng-europe were somewhat impromptu and uncertain. Enterprises don't react well to uncertainty. We can be critical and at the same time, not be hate-filled. Hate is an emotional thing and some commentary has been emotionally laced. It is fair to suggest that the Angular team would have done well to think through its roadmap and then put out a CFP. It is supposedly an OSS project after all and there is something to be said for treating the community as a dev partner. It is also fair to say that often, things just get changed for the sake of change because of the appearance that it is out of fashion. The latest commentary around 2 way binding and react.js that for the most part, treats 2 way binding as an anti-pattern are interesting. There are some valid technical arguments but the stated motivations and rationale are far from thoughtful. IMO, it's why we see so much half-baked stuff today that manifests in a lack of maturity. The wounds the Angular team is experiencing are largely self-inflicted. They need to do a better job at communication if they are interested in preserving the brand. In hindsight, they would have been well served to put this effort under a different moniker. Again, just my opinion.

I feel if they do make a major change with angular 2.0 then eventually the old version will die out. Mainly because the community at large will dwindle away for coming up with solutions for 1.0 questions. You know, everyone will all anwser UPGRADE to 2.x. Easy solution... Everyone will be more focused on the 2.0 development problems. I guess rewrite it is....

More and more often teams decide to abandon backward compatibility and I believe it to be the onsent of paradigm: develop, deploy, get real use cases and rethink everything from scratch taking new technologies into account - metagile ;)If old framework works and bugs get fixed who has ever told that it must evolve infinitely?

if AngularJS 2.0 is so radically different from 1.x, thus requiring a rewrite then why call it AngularJS? Why not start a new web framework based on AtScript and ECMA 6 web components? You can continue support of Angular 1.x, but when your new framework is baked and achieves strong adoption there will be a natural migration to the stronger framework.Announcing that the future evolution of a popular framework will not be backwards compatible, thus losing any investment in project development, tools, plugins, modules... It is suicide. Project managers will shy away from supporting the now terminal framework and look for others with a more bright future they can bank their project on.Sad, really. I love angular, it makes web app fun and highly productive.
Google is taking the risk of pushing the future to the present, and they will find resistance, but in the end we'll be there anyways... let's dive ES6!

I know what to do. And the answer is obvious. Don't use this POS framework. NOT 1.2, NOT 1.3, and NOT 2.0. It is a giant waste of time. It is not a good idea to build an enterprise level web application on a javscript FRAMEWORK. Notice I saw framework and not library. Angular hijacks your entire application and does not play well with other libraries and frameworks. Not to mention performance is horrible. Instead, what you should do is use vanilla.JS using the module pattern. For two way data binding you can use knockout when you NEED IT. A successful web application that has stood the test of time include knockout, jquery, require, and vanilla.JS. For routing you can do it yourself pretty easily or use crossroads if need be. I cannot think of a single reason why anyone would want to use this $hitty framework. It is a GIANT waste of time and is COMPLETELY unnecessary. My advice, LEARN JAVASCRIPT.

There r plenty of AngularJS 1x projects that are in active development or being planned. What do they do? By the time they are done - an incompatible AngularJS2x is staring at them.How does one explain this to the Business?"Yes the app is ready... but the support will dwindle ... so we have to rewrite it in a year's time again"

It will fork if needs be. There is just so much interest in AngularJS that a fork will happen if its 2.0 plans do not change. Jenkins/ Hudson is much better example than Silverlight. MSFT fan boys in general are quite different from the open source community in general, much of the MSFT community tend be in it for themselves and no-one else.

My two cents here are simple. The web development community has serious ADD issues. While progress always means moving forward, The pace that is demanded of the community is ravaging the businesses we support. In the end it's costing them billions by constantly pushing new and "better" fundamental code bases, requiring re-training and drastically affecting the overall stability of the web and the job security of many of us.We are simply making changes that are too drastic too quickly for business to match our pace. We need to slow down with the re-writes and settle down. We are driving the technology infrastructure of the global economies here, billions are depending on our work to power our world. This is why people see computers as "never working". Let's settle down as a community, Master what we need to as a community and produce quality deliverables with tried and true results.Right now when you look at NodeJS you can see what happens when the "kids get ahold of it", new "better" plugins that replace older plugins by adding one or two features and calling it a new package, instead of doing a pull request on the original source code and contributing to an existing product.Instead of the Angular team focusing on a re-write, affecting billions of dollars in technological infrastructure that we have amassed over the last few years to essentially guarantee their backlog remains full the team should be focused on _perfecting_ 1.3 and make it easier to learn and make the best practices the obvious course of action for new developers instead of something to look up on Stack Overflow.They are electing to make all of our established angular skills of utterly obsolete in literally version _2_ of the product.TypeScript has specific uses and has a place in the economy, but overall it has not been adopted because the lack of type safety is exactly what gives JavaScript a huge leg up on typed languages. I really think that the move to superset TypeScript is going to really making people cringe and shy away from angular 2 because we, as a community, DO NOT LIKE typescript. The sample code for the directive looked utterly cryptic. That's a bad thing. If it's a new version of a product it should not be an entirely new product. The changes to go from C++ to C# weren't as drastic as going from Angular 1.0 to Angular 2.0 ... That should give the team a serious degree of pause and give them a good reason for serious reflection.

Sorry to say this but people are so naive this days. It seems many people didn't watch the AngularJS 2 ng-Europe. The mistake here is they are calling it AngularJS 2 and that's wrong, It is complete from top to bottom another framework with another type of Typescript kind of language.So majority of people are complaining because to upgrade will need to throw to the garbage everything what we learn from AngularJS 1. They are just keeping the directives but scope,controllers and a bunch of others things are gone.So yes this would be a major re write for projects that already use AngularJS 1.I agree not just the web but all IT areas evolve fast and that is a good thing but we need somehow respect and support backward compatibility.This behavior seems like a child play or as someone said an experiment with no ethic and professionalism to understand that many multi-million dollar projects or group of professionals are depending on this code base.I will say really AnguarJS is a bad choice to depend your codebase for your exiting or new projects. Me personally I will be looking to EmberJS, This people seems to care more about backward compatibility or go back to Backnone.js and build my own framework around it.

The same story of GWT. He had a very short life.Even with jQuery you can do tow way data binding.That library of this kind no decreases the complexity of code, on the contrary.There preferred simple combinations bootstrap, foundation, purecss.io + jQuery or framework like YUI or better OpenUI5

Valentin: GWT has a short-life? GWT 3.0 is going to be announced in a month or two and it has never looked better. And there has been a relatively straightforward migration path all the way from 1.x. GWT is what you use to build serious stuff - Amazon's AWS console is built in it and so is the new Google Inbox application.And now there are multiple firms backing GWT - their existence is tied to it.

You point out potential problems that have already been pointed out (many times), tell people to not panic even though you don't provide a solution for said problems, you ask smart questions that you answer with "I don't know", so really, what's the point of this article? I can see it coming from the "angular's marketing or crisis management teams"... But you're not part of either, are you? I don't feel I learned anything new by reading this article, rendering it a pretty useless one IMO.

I find it alarming that the AngularJS team is taking such a dramatic next step. Essentially, this approach abandons the existing path in favor of an all new one -- and calls it AngularJS too just to pretend it's not something completely different. As a developer, I personally love to be able to do this. I learn from my mistakes and ditch them as soon as possible. However, as a business owner, I don't have this option.My company makes very important cloud-based applications which have a long life - somewhere around 10 to 15 years. A single customer installation is a $4-6 million multi-year effort. Our customers are the biggest and most important entities out there -- we don't get to abandon them when we're done. Furthermore, as time goes by, much other infrastructure around our core applications gets added, resulting is a very complex and sophisticated system. Asking our customers to cough up a few million for a complete rewrite as Google changed their mind and we can't support their older technology due to staff turnover and browser evolution isn't going to happen.If you're a website developer building websites with a short life, it's easy to simply dismiss the changes as necessary for progress. It's easy because you're not building a complex legacy which must be maintained. We need to hire and retain developers with the skills necessary to both initially develop but longer term, maintain, the systems we build. How can we reasonably depend on a framework if it's maker chooses to ditch it the next time a shiny new idea comes out?Repeatedly, I get the sense that anything Google should be avoided. It's not a company with the maturity to understand how to support their customers. Rather, it's a giant playground for adult kids to explore their ideas and whims without any business supervision.

It seems Angular developers will be left with the weight of maintaining 1.x applications and simultaneously trying to learn Angular 2.0, with not much of a bridge between 1.x and 2.0. This will leave developers frustrated, especially because many of the 1.x features gave one the feeling of "cool, this works", and now in 2.0 you can't do it that way anymore. There were changes to the jQuery library back in the day, but nothing, nothing at all compared to what the changes between Angular 1.x and 2.0 will be. Now, I doubt Angular is ubiquitous as jQuery, but can you imagine the backlash if the jQuery team had completely re-hauled jQuery?I think what is going to happen is lots of Angular 1.x developers are going to jump ship, unless the experience of Angular 2.0 is over-the-top developer-friendly. These jilted Angular 1.x developers are going to move to the Aurelia framework (and all the tech-ed folks will love it, because it means another new framework that needs tutorials!). But seriously, I think Aurelia is going to take away a large chunk of the Angular 1.x developers. The durandal blog post comparing the syntax of Angular 2.0 and Aurelia sure has me more interested in Aurelia than Angular.

I'm responsible a mid-sized AngularJS application. I've come to the same conclusions as you point out in your article. My application is still under heavy development. Do I move to a new technology now and have 100 files to migrate or do I wait for a couple years and have 500 files to migrate?
Nice post. If they really are dropping support for IE9 that will be a complete dealbreaker for quite a few companies I suspect. Angular 1.3x will probably stay around for a while.

I love AngularJS 1.x and couldn't imagine writing an app for the web platform without it. I really like what I'm seeing in AngularJS 2.0, too, and look forward to using it. All that's needed is a transition strategy better than "rewrite from scratch" and I think we'll end up in a good place.

Great post! Doesn't it say something about the code when people need a complete rewrite for a framework change? And do you really need to upgrade? Most enterprise apps I come across are in the 'it works so Don't f-ing touch it' state anyway. If angular 1.x solves your problem right now, it will still do that when 2.0 get released.

Hi Shawn,Thank you for this course it was excellent !I'm learning a lot from you !I've also discovered that WebStorm9 is so powerful that I decided to not start learning gulp or grunt because Web-storm make a lot of their tasks ( and it's so easy..).But if you advise me to learn one of them, Should I learn gulp or grunt?Cordially
Hi Shawn, fantastic course on WebStorm! Excellent coverage on broad range of usage scenerios. Appreciate all you do for the developer community!

Shawn:IDE courses are virtually always banal and humdrum. All too often they play like a press release. Yet I keep looking for them because the Intellij tools are so powerful and promising that I knew I was just scratching the surface.Your course rocks. Every module yields new tips, tricks, and insights. I've already upped my game with new settings, new shortcuts, and (real soon now) new workflow productivity. Your "Live Editing" introduction, demonstration, and walk through alone was worth the price of admission.Intellij should pay you (& Pluralsight) to release your course for freely available for ALL their web related tools --- as it is an invaluable eye-opener. No joke. I use RubyMine but am delighted I took the time for your WebStorm course.Thank you for your pleasant tone, excellent explanations, generous workflow suggestions, and well paced, matter of fact mentoring.Kudos & Thank You!

Great course man. I am very familiar with Visual Studio and you bridged the gap pretty effortlessly. Also, you seem to present the material in a semi interesting way(lets be serious, learning about an IDE isn't as fun as coding). Cheers

item.title: Angular 1.3 and Breaking Change for Controllers

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: Hi Shawn, You said Bootsrap 4. Did you mean 3 (3.3.0)? There isn't too much info about version 4. It looks like it wouldn't be released soon.Ruslan

I ran into this exact issue a little over a week ago when I updated an app to Angular 1.3. I posted on the AngularJS google group and was pointed to the github documentation of this change by https://github.com/angular/angular.js/commit/3f2232b5a181512fac23775b1df4a6ebda67d018

Just for those that ran into this problem while taking the Pluralsight Building a Site with Bootstrap, AngularJS, ASP.NET, EF and Azure like me.In index.cshtml, change:<div data-ng-controller="homeIndexController"> to <div ng-app="myapp" ng-controller="homeIndexController">You have to remove the "data-" prefix.And home-index.js should be:var app = angular.module("myapp", []); app.controller("homeIndexController", function ($scope, $http) { $scope.data = []; $scope.isBusy = true; $http.get("/api/v1/topics?includeReplies=true") .then(function (result) { // success angular.copy(result.data, $scope.data); }, function () { // error alert("could not load topics"); }) .then(function () { $scope.isBusy = false; });});Thanks for the web site and the classes!

RE: Boostrap 4, AngularJS 1.3, ASP.NET vNext, EF7 updated course version on Pluralsight... You say?That really sounds like a very wise initiative. Sure will keep a close look on this one. In the meantime thanks for sharing the info...
I was also able to apply @Scott Collier's fix but keep the ng-app directive in the _Layout.cshtml file's "html" tag. Great course Shawn, look forward to the updated version, thanks.

Also if you happen to be working through the Pluralsight course and you're on module 8 section 2, you may run into an issue where you get an 'unknown provider' error from Angular. If you'd previously already fixed the issue mentioned in this post, you may also need to declare the dependency on ngRoute, as in:var module = angular.module('homeIndex', ['ngRoute']);(because apparently when the course was done, ngRoute was not in a separate .js file from angular)thx dB
Thanks Shawn, will take a look.

What if you do something like:var app = angular.module("myapp", []);app.controller('homeController', homeCtrl);function homeCtrl($scope){ ... };I haven't checked, but I write this way since in 1.2 it's how the ng-modules are written (well, some of them) so I adopted it as a best practice. Apologize for the laziness on my part, but I think it would be an important thing to point out in this blog post.

This is a little nuanced (ie nitpicky), but this would be a similar fix:app.controller("homeController", homeController); And might be easier to apply since it's one line and you wouldn't need to modify function homeController, or find the end to place your );

In regards to Scott Collier post. In Layout.cshtml ng-app attribute shall be populated with your angular.module name.*.jsvar app = angular.module("myApp", []);Layout.cshtml<html lang="en" ng-app=" myApp">

I would like to encourage all of you really like your blog. Did you design this website yourself or did you hire someone to do it for you? Plz reply as Im looking to create my own blog and would like to find out where u got this from. many thanks bookmark this page to your most used service to help get the word out.
Hi Shawn - Liked your project, sorry to see it go! I would check out CanIStream.it if you haven't yet, which is a similar service that was permitted by Netflix to remain active.

The problem with CanIStream.it is their information is wrong. Go search for Top Gun - says Xbox and Amazon have it for "Digital Purchase" only - that's wrong, and has been wrong for several months. So - what's the good of a service like that which is providing incorrect information? You go to the site, see what it says, but then check your providers anyway?

Thanks for the insight that your experience provided. I never used the app but had been thinking I needed it lately when the wife wants to watch a certain movie and I don't know if it's on U-verse, my premium channels, Netflix, Amazon Prime, or Hulu Plus. Maybe you were just ahead of the market. Still it's a damn shame that Netflix can't provide an API since they are making plenty of money.
Hey Shawn,glad you enjoyed your time in Köln. We definitely enjoyed seeing you on the stage make the web API 2 magic work. Good session.
Thanks for sharing your insights of WebAPI with us. I think I learned a lot from your presentation, it certainly did get me started on WebAPI.

item.title: Visual Studio and WebStorm: Am I Mad?

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: Using WebStorm for frontend work and VS for backend absolutely makes sense. But working with them on the same project / solution? That's a firm NO. Actually that is not true, because I'm forced to use it like this and let me tell you it's a nightmare I very desperately tried to get rid of.When you have a VS solution for both front-end and backend things get messy:- When you are in WebStorm you can't add new files or delete existing ones. VS project files will never know about it... Or wait you can? => Yes you can! You can use wildcard inclusions! But what about the node_modules folder? That will pass the length of 250 characters (In 2014 WTF Microsoft???) so the Azure project just won't run locally and can't be packaged... that's it... Or can you get around this? => Yes you can! Use wildcard exclusions in the project file!. Okay no more problems for tooling now... but... if you move a file in VS or duplicate or something these inclusions can't handle nicely... your project file get's messed up again! It's an endless nightmare... These tools are not designed to work on the same project.- What about integating with MVC? Yeah... been there. I even went on to implement Html Helpers which were generating angularjs html code bits based on the DTO type and metadata... which in case of form was just amazingly productive... Unfortunately... yeah you guessed it. It introduces a lot of limitations you don't want to accept. The whole min + html2js + whatever process u like in other angular projects is not usable with gulp or grunt because you go through the ASP.NET MVC stack (BundleTransofmration). You can't do proper "live reload" becuase it is just extremely slow! (The more complex your project gets....)My advice: Have a backend VS project and have a separate frontend WebStorm project and solve the integration / deployment with tools both on local and uat / production / whatever environment.... You'll get a lot less pain. But yes, I still want to use WebStorm... :)

In home I use modified https://visualstudiogallery.msdn.microsoft.com/e376f2f7-4412-4b75-8ccf-818c45adafe5 template (folder pub renamed to dist and newest nuget packages) and combo Visual Studio WebStorm (with yeoman and generator-gulp-angular) do the trick. In standard MVC project I agree it is hell but in such sliced and diced template it just works.
Shawn I started using WebStorm a few months ago and am really impressed with it. Tough to beat for developing JS heavy apps - Angular etc.
I wonder what your view on this is, now that the launch of Visual Studio 2015 with it's many JavaScript Editor Improvements is near ?

I work with both VS and WebStorm (PHPStorm) everyday so I know what I say. PHPStorm which is the same animal as WebStorm is not so good as it seems. Two things that make me sad when I work with PHPStorm is:1. Code completion. It's terrible compared to Intellisense. It just gives you everyhing it finds in project files. Create js file in WebStom 9, create variable x of type string and hit dot - what you see? An endless list of unrelated properties and methods right after string methods. And what if I work with non built-in objects? The code completion becomes totally useless showing you just everything.2. HTML formatting. It's terrible too compared to VS 2013. When I hit Ctrl+K+F in VS 2013 I can be sure it formats the code properly and it does. I cannot say the same about Webstorm. When I hit Alt+F8 to auto-format HTML in WebStorm it often gives me a lot of frustration. Then I need to manually change everytning.VS cannot be compared to WebStorm. WebStorm is made on a hurry with little thought of the future and a lot of bugs that developers even don't try to resolve. It just tries to support everything that is popular today. VS is more general and doesn't try to do everything but what it does it does good enough.And no, I don't work at Microsoft :)

Well, Ben, the reason is that the Intellisense for Visual Studio JavaScript is really bad and makes unhelpful suggestions, while WebStorm is good and can even infer stuff like controller names and properties for directives you specified in angular.
Everyone says WebStorm is better for js but no one ever says why.

Totally agree with you. Writing JavaScript and Angular on WebStorm is fun. I use it for any front-end work I do. I didn't have to use it side-by-side with Visual Studio; but your point makes sense to me.
More comfortabele than the Mean stack Shawn?
Waiting for your blog series on this !!

Nice post Shawn.I love the changes and direction overall. But have we gone far enough?I have some questions that fall into categories such as "you moved my cheese" , "why invent something new", "why not make a complete game changing shift?", and "why be slow?".Let' me start backwards with "why be slow?". I've been through years of Microsoft pre-releases and I love the early looks. And I've grown to be comfortable with the trade off of seeing new features in an early state but giving up the speed/perf that gets sacrificed in these. It's a fair deal. But I'm looking at this from a new angle as I see more folks approaching this platform and wondering why it has to be slow. Is that the first impression a company wants folks to have with its product? I think it's unfortunate because the tools are great and power ful, but the speed and quirks are awful right now. In fact, I've had such a poor time with the previews that I stopped using them. So my plea here is for the new Microsoft to find a way to release previews that have quirks, but aren't so slow. Big ask, yes. Will folks who love Microsoft (like I do) flame me? Yep. But if they truly want newcomers to have a great first experience, it has to be done.Moving on to "why invent something new?" ... if we state that the wwwroot idea is to keep whats public separate from whats in dev, let's explore why this doesnt work this way in OSS JavaScript and Web now. Many projects use a build system like grunt or gulp (which Microsoft is embracing, so kudos to them!) and already put their build/dist/public code in a folder. They just dont call it wwwroot. But the folder name and where it goes and how you do it is debateable. I dont have a problem with someone using this folder but I do think its a bit silly to adopt this as the MSFT way when so many projects out there already have a folder exposes, and can choose to tailor it using their own code. I think this was a solution in need of a problem, personally, and have seen it cause a few experienced early adopter devs struggles already. Chuck the wwwroot concept. Let devs choose how to do it, or if at all. I've heard the argument from the team that if they dont do this, everything is exposed. Not so ... I dont serve from my dev code on my laptop, I serve from a web server and what goes there doesnt look like what is in my dev code. Thats where the choice and customization of a build/dist folder comes in. Forcing wwwroot and the things that go with it is something I have seen folks struggle with, and personally I'm not on board that train. It's not killer, but its an example of "why did we invent something new here?""you moved my cheese" ... I am so with you on the web api and mvc merging. I can see why they did it, but it's not something I like. Maybe its because I often use web api with MVC and I like the separation. But maybe its just the inevitable feeling that I am not used to it. Not a major deal, and it is an expected change as with every new version.Finally, "why not make a complete game changing shift?" ... they have done a lot. i admit that the project K concepts are awesome. They will be fast. They are modelled after node (at least they appear to be so). But why stop here? There are some awesome features in client side development that seem to be predicated on using server side tools and code to generate client side code. I think they are great ... but where it the client side feel? Where it the full blown node integration? Where is Visual Studio for a Mac? I think we may see some of these in teh future. I am actually very hopefully optimistic that we will. But I still feel that there is a bit of a tight hold on the past, when its time to be a game changer. As I started ....I love the direction ... i just feel that there are some places that Microsoft could really blow the doors off this thing and make a huge impact. I'm hoping that's where Microsoft leads the way.
I suppose my preference for rendering markup using a Web API formatter is no longer useful. :( I'm very sad about the changes to Web API.

Thanks for your impressions, Shawn. I'm looking forward to your series.As I chew on your post and the comments so far from John and Ryan, I find myself taking a big step back to ponder what ASP vNext is all about. What's the mission statement that supports the specific choices we see emerging in this product?Reading backward from the preview, it seems the top priority is "Retain the base of ASP.NET developers"The top threat is that that base is leaking and the allegiance to Microsoft is leaking with it. One big reason is that it is manifestly cheaper and easier to develop with rival tools and technologies. This isn't simply a matter of making MS tech free. That helps (see VS, Community Edition) but it isn't enough. MS had to do much more to free ASP from legacy baggage and bring the flexibility, openness, and speed of rival platforms into the ASP world ... so that ASP developers don't feel ridiculously hamstrung and inferior in comparison.While this interest DRIVES the changes, it also constrains the CHANGES. If MS simply reproduced what others have done, it would have no perceived advantage over rivals and nothing special to offer the developers it hopes to retain.The unique value of ASP.NET is that it remains a .NET product. You write in C# (not JavaScript, not Ruby, not Java). You get to use Visual Studio. You have a reasonable chance of re-using your existing back-end .NET investments .... or at least have a shorter, more familiar porting path.If retention is the top priority, then they have to minimize obstacles to conversion even if that means less flexibility and fewer of the niceties in other platforms. Yes, node/express give you much more choice in how and what you expose to the web; "wwwroot" is far more limiting. But one could argue that the simplicity of "wwwroot" (especially if it facilitates VS tooling) does more for developer retention than is lost to flexibility. I'd like to see John's counter argument.I agree, Ryan, that subsuming Web API under MVC is a technology shame. They certainly could have implemented view generation as a formatter. That would open the door to the many alternative view generation engines out there today (the node developer has at least five popular engines to choose from). But separate MVC and Web API stacks have proven problematic for the ASP community who have clamored for unification. The MVC set is far larger than the Web API set. It's pretty clear which one has to dominate the discussion. It's pretty clear which sub-community needs to be courted most assiduously. Now the whole venture flops if ASP vNext fails to be fast, flexible and open. The openness to grunt and gulp (and bower and npm) are aligned with that direction and ... this is important ... there is no significant MS constituency that loves the existing configuration and build system; MS offends no one by killing them.What about non-MS developers? How will MS compete for today's node, Ruby, Java developers? Frankly, I don't think they can. It would be nice. But vNext succeeds with or without them. It only succeeds if it retains .NET developers who would otherwise flee. Mac tooling? Nice. Sublime? Brackets? VIM? ... all good stuff. Those initiatives augment the primary mission of retaining .NET developers. But moving too much cheese? That's not going to work. Making it difficult for the masses to transition to vNext? That's not going to work either.Accordingly, we must be prepared to accept some technological sacrifices - and a good deal of forward thinking - if vNext is to succeed at all.

Shawn,Why do we need a thing called wwwroot? Node doesnt give you this out of the box, so I disagree with you there. We create one on our own as needed, with no constraints. if its there, its there, but I dont agree with putting it there out of the boxYou and I dont hold the slowness against them. That was my point. But if you want new folks to come in, if their first experience is slow, that's not good. I think we can do better. We give a free pass to the team because we know them and love them. But we need to stretch.Yep ... agree on the cheese. I can deal with it. It happens all the time. No different here than it is on other platforms.
I have been using NancyFx for the past 2 years because routes and DI is just some much simpler. Shawn, can you draw any distinctions between vNext and Nancy? Are the similarities?

I'll caveat my comments by saying that I have yet to spend any substantial time trying to build anything with the new bits. But I have monitored insiders conversations, conference sessions, and discussions like this closely.I'm all for moving my cheese if it is to get it out the way of the new delectable dish that is hiding behind it. But I can't help walking away from a lot of these lurking sessions with a feeling that they moved the cheese just to move it. There is a lot of focus on how things are different to get the same old things done a different way. Where is the concise list of new things I can do that I never could before, or at least examples of how the things I do now with ASP.current are oh so much better with vNext? I seem to be missing those.

Great points Brian. I'm not sure of the answer, but I'd like to hear more about that. Shawn is right that we are shedding some overhead that really isn't needed ... many platforms have lighter weight baggage than .NET, and the new .NET has adopted that mentality, which I like. project.json is a much cleaner step than the days of global.asax. web.config, and so on. But I'd like to hear more of the compelling movitations that you search for.Ward, if retention is their goal, then I think you are right as there is not much reason to strive for more. But is retention a good business long term strategy? Maybe it works for some companies, but I'd like to think Microsoft wants to gain, not tread water. But maybe they need to tread first. We shall see. However... I do not think this is what they are doing, I think they are shooting for more, thus my comments.I think they are doing more that retaining. Let's look at the shift ... they have rearchitected ASP.NET, upped the tooling, adopted node, grunt, gulp and hopefully soon other tools like yeoman and karma. They are striving for faster with their tools and platform. All of these are awesome, and I commend these efforts. But while they are modelling after proven popular techniques, they are making it in their own likeness ... in their own mold. I like theat they put twists on here, even if some are uncomfortable. This is not, IMO, an effort to retain but instead an effort to make an impact. Woudl I like them to go further? Yes. Seize the opportunity.I have faith that ASP.NET, Visual Studio and Azure will forge a new path.

Nice points, Brian and Ward. I'm a bit biased towards OWIN having worked on it for a long time. However, I was a little surprised OWIN was not more of the core reason to move the cheese. It's sort of tacked on as an adapter layer. That's fine, at least I can still use all my OWIN stuff wherever ASP.NET goes. Nevertheless, I'm glad that ASP.NET is free of the tight coupling to the IIS programming model.I don't know how many others out there really care about OWIN. It's likely a small number. The same can be said for vNext, I think. Contrary to Ward's points, I know very few people who think badly of MSBuild, the *proj formats, global.asax, and Web Forms. I will not be surprised to see a very slow uptake of vNext among the mass of .NET web developers.For those of us who fight some of those conventions, vNext is a huge win. But I see that win primarily in terms of tooling. I don't really notice a major change in the MVC model. Web Pages is going to be a sort of Ember/Angular style magic around MVC, and Web API, as noted earlier, has finally been completely subsumed into the maw of MVC. (I still miss the arguably better model in WCF Web API).<aside>To Ward's point on Web API, I think you are correct. It had to happen. I still mourn its loss. However, I can still call upon Nancy [1], Frank [2], and now Freya [3] to help me out in dark times of trouble. In fact, I can't say I've used MVC at all except to see what the project templates generate, and I've used Web API in such a minimal way that I suppose I'm not really losing anything with the above options available to me.By the way, if you are interested in a very different style of web programming in .NET, especially if you would like to follow HTTP but think less about how to do so when coding your apps, do check out Freya. You can find a rough intro slide deck here: http://freya-fs.github.io/freya.intro. Docs and more samples are coming. We have a goal to ensure this runs well in vNext but haven't started that process. It runs directly on top of OWIN and provides a web machine [4] style programming model following the HTTP state machine [5]. If you are curious as to why this sort of model is a good idea, please read "HTTP, Hell No!" [6] (from the Forget HTTP project [7]).</aside>[1] http://nancyfx.org/[2] http://frankfs.net/[3] https://github.com/freya-fs/freya[4] https://github.com/basho/webmachine/wiki[5] https://github.com/for-GET/http-decision-diagram[6] http://hyperrest.github.io/2013-06-10-http-hell-no/[7] https://github.com/for-GET/README

My first impressions about vNext is a late MS response to NodeJS world. Very easy to see MS trying to give to ASP the power of NodeJS does, but in a wrong way.The first of all, .NET is a "typed environment", so we can't call a function (without 'dynamic') that only existed in the future, or even variable. It is great!!!We can do everything with JS. Is it great too!The problem is that MS are creating a world that I call "mixed typed framework" (lambda, anonymous, etc), breaking the .NET essence.For example, how to vNext app startup? And the "use" for Http pipeline? Many vNext behavior works using reflections. We must create a method named "xyz" with parameters "xyz" exactly how the framework want. We are losing the elegance of "create an Interface xyz which implements xyz method". .NET was not created for it!Another problem is the MVP stack that never expose critics about MS technologies. I remember many MVP saying beautiful workds about Silverlight, XAML, etc. Am I seeing again for vNext?MS will create vNext to run on Win,Mac and Linux, but I know this history. The "easy way" will be MS plataforms, and many others we must doing by hands. Try now vNext on Mac/Linux! Remember, to run vNext on Mac/Linux Mono must be FULLY compatible. Remember again, MS said in the first version of .NET that ".NET will be multi-language and multi-plataform". Who turned it multi-plataform? Read more about Mono-Project to see how hard was to do it without MS help.IMHO, we don't need more MS stack to create greats web/mobile apps. For me, .NET is now only good for Desktop apps.The web world are changing the oportunities and I can't see MS on there.
Alexandro,.NET Core will be replacing "underground" mono runtime everywhere soon; so I expect MS will support other platforms the same as windows (not sure if not even more...)

item.title: A Look at ASP.NET 5: Part 2 - Startup

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: Nice...so with the ConfigureServices method we now have in house support for dependency injection ... so we need not use external libraries like Ninject etc... right Shawn ?

Global.asax had event handlers which might be confusing, but ConfigureServices and Configure (these names are not well chosen btw) are also confusing, if there's an order in them in the way they're called. Why not 1 method: Configure; that would be simple, now there are two, and one is called 'Configure' meaning 'hey, this configures it' but not quite, there's another configure, namely for services.

Ravi,Nothing prevents you from splitting out concerns if Startup becomes too complex. Create a RouteConfig class define all your configuration there and instantiate it from Startup. I like the idea of a centralized startpoint. On large projects it probably will be split out but that will be a design decision by the developer not some behind the scenes "magic".

Shawn,First of all, excellent post. Thanks for the great information.However, it appears as if Configure() method is trying to do a lot of things. I don't see an advantage, for example, of taking away RouteConfig.cs and try to map routes in Configure() method. Does it mean that any new routing needs to be added in Startup.cs?
I love this series. So easy to catch up if you are not following the all the beta bits. Just the right amount information to understand the new bits.
Great intro Shawn. Thanks for sharing on your blog.

My point is that the Configure method could also have been designed to receive the IServiceCollection object and you then do the configuration of these there. Coming to the Startup class it now is confusing what to place where (to me at least), also because you can do initialization of services in Configure: https://github.com/aspnet/Mvc/blob/dev/test/WebSites/BasicWebSite/Startup.cs#L18It's now unclear why there are two and not just one: when there are two they obviously have a reason to be there, which is thus important to know for the developer and that IMHO leads to confusion unless you know what to put where (e.g. similar to global.asax). Fowler said on twitter the ConfigureServices was added for e.g. EF migrations which don't need the HTTP pipeline (so don't use Configure), but my question why one would use ASPNET and not HTTP was left unanswered. (as I then would assume an app doing migrations and not http would be using another run vehicle than aspnet, but if that's not the case, it indeed makes sense to have two methods. The use case though remains unclear to me. (and therefore it's imho confusing).

I'm using the following code:services.Configure<CookieAuthenticationOptions>(options => { options.Notifications = new CookieAuthenticationNotifications { OnApplyRedirect = ctx => { if (!ctx.Request.Path.StartsWithSegments(new PathString("/api")) && ctx.Request.Path.Value.ToLower() != "/token" && ctx.Request.Path.Value.ToLower() != "/signout") { ctx.Response.Redirect(ctx.RedirectUri); } } }; });

Last changes is:services.AddCookieAuthentication(config => { config.LoginPath = "/Auth/Login"; config.Events = new CookieAuthenticationEvents() { OnRedirect = ctx => { if (ctx.Request.Path.StartsWithSegments("/api") && ctx.Response.StatusCode == 200) { ctx.Response.StatusCode = (int)HttpStatusCode.Unauthorized; return Task.FromResult<object>(null); } else { ctx.Response.Redirect(ctx.RedirectUri); return Task.FromResult<object>(null); } } }; });
Do you plan on doing a course on REST API's using bearer tokens when more stable versions of ASP 5 are released?

There have been several changes to this in later beta releases. Now use services.AddIdentity method with IdentityOptions parameter. Notifications are now under Cookies.ApplicationCookie.Events and the event will be OnRedirectToLogin. Hope this helps others.
